questions.text: A 25-year-old female patient presented to the emergency with pneumothorax. Which of the following is indication for surgical management?
questions.solution:
Pneumothorax and ICD insertion

  • all of the given options are indications for surgical intervention in pneumothorax.

Inserting and managing a chest drain

An intercostal tube connected to an underwater seal is central to the management of chest disease. The safest site for the insertion of a drain is in the triangle that lies:

  • anterior to the mid-axillary line;
  • above the level of the nipple;
  • below and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle.

This will ideally find the fifth space. The technique includes the following.

  • Sterility: Maintain strict sterility throughout the procedure.
  • Anaesthesia: Ensure adequate local anaesthesia, including the pleura.
  • Dissection: Use sharp dissection for the skin and blunt dissection with artery forceps through muscle layers, aiming to avoid air entrapment.
  • Drain Placement:
    • For pneumothorax/haemothorax: Position the drain towards the apex of the lung.
    • For pleural effusion/empyema: Position the drain near the lung base. Always insert over the upper edge of the rib to avoid the neurovascular bundle below.
  • Stitching: Secure the retaining stitch; omit in empyema cases for better drainage.
  • Connection: Attach the drain to an underwater seal for a one-way valve function.
  • Post-procedure: Confirm correct drain placement with a chest X-ray; avoid clamping the drain.

Explanation:

Option A. First contralateral pneumothorax: Correct. The recurrence of pneumothorax on the opposite side is an indication for surgery.

Option B. Bilateral spontaneous pneumothorax: Correct. Bilateral pneumothorax presents an increased risk and is often managed surgically.

Option C. Pregnancy: Correct. Pregnancy is an indication for surgical management due to the need to prevent recurrence and respiratory complications during gestation.

Option D. All of the above: Correct. Each of the above scenarios is a valid indication for surgical intervention in the case of pneumothorax.

Key points:

  • Surgical intervention is indicated for recurrent pneumothorax, bilateral involvement, or in special cases such as pregnancy. The main goal is to prevent recurrence and improve patient outcomes.

questions.text: What will be T staging for 1.5 cm lung carcinoma, which is involving the pericardium?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Option A. T1a: Incorrect. T1a refers to tumors ≤1 cm in size without invasion of surrounding structures, limited to the lung parenchyma.

Option B. T1b: Incorrect. T1b refers to tumors between 1 and 2 cm, still without invasion of surrounding structures like the pericardium.

Option C. T3: Correct. T3 refers to tumors that invade adjacent structures such as the pericardium, chest wall, or diaphragm, regardless of size.

Option D. T2: Incorrect. T2 refers to tumors between 2 and 5 cm or those that invade visceral pleura but not adjacent structures like the pericardium.

Key points:

  • T3 staging is applied for lung carcinomas invading adjacent structures such as the pericardium, irrespective of the tumor size.

questions.text: 76 year muruganandam, chronic smoker presented with complaints of weight loss, coughing for more than 6 months. What is the most common cancer involved in hypercalcemia?
questions.solution:
Histological classification of lung cancer

  • Small Cell Lung Cancer (SCLC):
    • Known as oat cell cancer, a type of neuroendocrine tumor (NET).
    • Represents about 20% of all lung cancers.
    • Early metastasis via lymphatic and blood spread.
    • Highly responsive to chemotherapy but rarely cured.
    • Surgery is rarely offered unless in very limited disease stages.
  • Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer (NSCLC):
    • Adenocarcinoma: Now the most common NSCLC, increasing in women, possibly due to deep inhalation of low-tar cigarettes.
    • Squamous Carcinoma: Typically appears as a cavitating tumor.
    • Large Cell Undifferentiated Cancer: Part of NETs, occurs in both central and peripheral bronchi, slow-growing, and highly vascular.
  • Neuroendocrine Tumors (NETs) of the Lung:
    • Include small cell cancer, large cell undifferentiated lung cancer, and carcinoid tumors.
    • Carcinoid tumors are slow-growing, highly vascular, and mostly benign with excellent prognosis after surgical resection.
    • Carcinoid syndrome is rare unless metastatic.

Explanation: Squamous cell carcinoma

Option A. Squamous cell carcinoma: Correct. Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung is the most common lung cancer associated with hypercalcemia. This is due to the secretion of parathyroid hormone-related protein (PTHrP), leading to increased calcium levels in the blood.

Option B. Small cell carcinoma: Incorrect. Small cell carcinoma is commonly associated with the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH) rather than hypercalcemia.

Option C. Large anaplastic carcinoma: Incorrect. Large cell carcinoma is less frequently associated with hypercalcemia compared to squamous cell carcinoma.

Option D. Adenocarcinoma: Incorrect. Adenocarcinoma of the lung is typically associated with paraneoplastic syndromes involving the lungs and pleura but is not the most common cause of hypercalcemia

KEY POINTS:

  • Peripheral Neuropathy is an immune- mediated paraneoplastic syndrome due to secretion of antigens normally expressed only by the nervous system which leads to antibodies production against CNS.
  • Hypercalcemia is due to secretion of parathyroid-like hormones.
  • Hyponatremia due to SIADH.

questions.text: As an intern you are assisting a resident doctor in case of tension pneumothorax. Identify the incorrect statement about placement of ICD tube.
questions.solution:
Inserting and managing a chest drain

An intercostal tube connected to an underwater seal is central to the management of chest disease; however, the management of the pleura and of chest drains can be troublesome, even in experienced hands.

The safest site for insertion of a drain is in the triangle that lies:

  • Anterior to the mid-axillary line;
  • Above the level of the nipple;
  • Below and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle.

This will ideally find the fifth space. The technique includes the following.

  • Sterility: Maintain strict sterility throughout the procedure.
  • Anaesthesia: Ensure adequate local anaesthesia, including the pleura.
  • Dissection: Use sharp dissection for the skin and blunt dissection with artery forceps through muscle layers, aiming to avoid air entrapment.
  • Drain Placement:
    • For pneumothorax/haemothorax: Position the drain towards the apex of the lung.
    • For pleural effusion/empyaema: Position the drain near the lung base.Always insert over the upper edge of the rib to avoid the neurovascular bundle below.
  • Stitching: Secure the retaining stitch; omit in empyema cases for better drainage.
  • Connection: Attach the drain to an underwater seal for a one-way valve function.
  • Post-procedure: Confirm correct drain placement with a chest X-ray; avoid clamping the drain.

Explanation:

Option A. Identify 5th IC space anterior to mid axillary line: Correct. The 5th intercostal space at the anterior axillary or mid-axillary line is the recommended site for inserting an intercostal drainage (ICD) tube in cases of tension pneumothorax. This location provides optimal access while avoiding important structures.

Option B. Direct the tube posteriorly: Correct. The tube is directed posteriorly to ensure it effectively drains both air and fluid from the pleural cavity.

Option C. Insert along lower border of upper rib: Incorrect. The ICD tube should be inserted along the upper border of the rib to avoid injury to the neurovascular bundle (which runs along the lower border of each rib). Inserting along the lower border increases the risk of damaging the intercostal vessels and nerves.

Option D. Incise and digitally explore pleura prior to insertion: Correct. Making an incision and digitally exploring the pleural cavity helps to ensure correct placement and avoid lung or other tissue injury.

Bethesda classification system used to stage thymomas

questions.text: Identify wrong statement regarding mediastinal mass:
questions.solution:
Thymoma

  • Most common mediastinal tumor, accounting for 25% of all mediastinal tumors, originating from the thymus gland.
  • Behavior varies from benign to aggressively invasive.
  • Masaoka and TNM classification systems are used to stage thymomas.
  • Frequently associated with myasthenia gravis; thymectomy may improve symptoms even without the presence of thymoma.
  • Capsular invasion is the only reliable indicator of malignancy.
  • Treatment involves complete thymectomy. For large tumors (>5 cm) or suspected invasion, median sternotomy is performed. VATS or transcervical approaches are considered for smaller tumors or for myasthenia gravis treatment.
  • Pericardial cysts and Bronchogenic cysts are seen in middle mediastinum
  • Neurogenic tumours are the most common primary tumours of the posterior mediastinum.
  • Schwannomas and Neurilemomas are the most common neurogenic tumors.
  • Most common tumour of middle mediastinum: Lymphoma.
  • Most common mass of middle mediastinum: Pericardial Cyst.

Explanation:

Option A. Thymoma is the most common mediastinal tumour: Correct. Thymoma is indeed the most common primary tumor of the anterior mediastinum in adults. It is often associated with myasthenia gravis and other paraneoplastic syndromes.

Option B. Schwannomas and Neurilemomas are the most common neurogenic tumors: Correct. Schwannomas and Neurilemomas are the most common types of neurogenic tumors found in the posterior mediastinum.

Option C. VATS used for thymoma surgery: Correct. Video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS) is commonly used for the resection of thymomas, especially for early-stage thymomas.

Option D. Bethesda classification system used to stage thymomas: Incorrect. The Bethesda classification is not used to stage thymomas; it is used for thyroid cytology. Thymomas are staged using the Masaoka-Koga classification system, which is the most widely accepted method for staging thymomas based on the extent of tumor invasion.

questions.text: Not a methods of myocardial protection.
questions.solution:
Myocardial Protection in Cardiac Surgery

  • Cross-clamping the aorta stops coronary blood flow, causing the heart to become anoxic, necessitating myocardial protection to avoid damage within 15-20 minutes.
  • Cardioplegia solutions (commonly potassium) arrest the heart in diastole by depolarizing the myocyte membrane.
  • Cold solutions (4-10°C) reduce metabolic needs through hypothermia, while warm solutions may help in postoperative myocardial recovery.
  • Cardioplegia solutions need to be repeated every 15-20 minutes, or single-dose solutions are used for longer operations.
  • Intermittent cross-clamp fibrillationballows brief periods of ischaemia (10-20 minutes) with intermittent reperfusion.Intermittent cross-clamp fibrillation is a technique in which intermittent ventricular fibrillation (VF) is induced by a small electrical charge.
  • Total circulatory arrest is used for complex procedures (e.g., paediatric or aortic arch surgery) with core body temperature reduced to 15-18°C, allowing up to 20-30 minutes of circulatory arrest.

EXPLANATION:

Option A, B, C- Methods of myocardial protection include

  • intracoronary infusion of a cardioplegic solution (antegrade),
  • infusion via the coronary sinus (retrograde),
  • intermittent cross clamp fibrillation
  • total circulatory arrest.

Option D - infusion via the IVC. Incorrect.

Key Points:

  • Cardioplegia prevents myocardial damage.
  • Temperature control and intermittent reperfusion are crucial for myocardial protection.

Indications for surgery(CABG)

  • >50% stenosis of the left main stem ("critical left main stem disease")
  • >50% stenosis of the proximal left anterior interventricular artery
  • Three main coronary arteries diseased ("triple-vessel disease")
  • Two-vessel disease including the proximal LAD

Option A, B, C are correct.

Option D:

  • Two-vessel disease including the proximal LAD is indication for CABG .

questions.text: Kanchanben was diagnosed with lung cancer one month back, and presented with shortness of breath. On examination, the Kussmaul sign was positive. Heart sounds are distant and breath sounds appear reduced on the left side infra-scapular area. Requisition for chest X-ray is done and shown below. Comment on the diagnosis of the patient:
questions.solution:
Pericardial effusion

  • Pericardial Effusion:
    • Results from imbalance in the production and resorption of pericardial fluid.
  • Tamponade:
    • Occurs when pressure in the pericardium exceeds atrial pressure, leading to reduced venous return and compromised circulation. It can be gradual (e.g., malignancy) or acute (e.g., trauma, surgery).
  • Clinical Features:
    • Low blood pressure, raised jugular venous pressure, paradoxical pulse, and Kussmaul's sign (jugular venous pressure rises with inspiration).
  • Emergency Treatment:
    • Pericardial aspiration with a wide-bore needle temporarily relieves tamponade until further management (e.g., median sternotomy) is determined.
  • Chronic Tamponade:
    • Often due to malignancy (breast or bronchial cancer) or other conditions like uraemia or connective tissue disease. May require a pericardial window for long-term relief.

Explanation:

Option A. Pleural effusion: Unlikely as it doesn't explain distant heart sounds or Kussmaul sign.

Option B. Congestive heart failure: CHF presents with fluid overload but not with distant heart sounds and Kussmaul sign.

Option C. Cardiac tamponade: Correct. Distant heart sounds, Kussmaul sign, and shortness of breath are classic for cardiac tamponade, often seen in lung cancer with pericardial involvement.

Option D. SVC syndrome: Causes venous distension but lacks the characteristic heart and lung findings.

Key points:

Cardiac tamponade presents with distant heart sounds, Kussmaul sign, and shortness of breath, often due to pericardial effusion in lung cancer.

questions.text: 20 years old girl presents with Symptoms of thoracic outlet syndrome. which can be reproduced when the patient has both arms in the 90° abduction-external rotation position and asked to open and close the hands slowly over a 3-minute period. This provocative test is called?
questions.solution:
The test described in the question is a provocative test for thoracic outlet syndrome called Roos test (Elevated arm stress test).

Provocative tests for Thoracic Outlet Syndrome:

Option A: Adson test (Scalene Manoeuvre):

The examiner locates the radial pulse and the patient is asked

  • to Turn the head towards the affected side
  • Extend the neck
  • Take deep breath and hold

Inference: A positive test is indicated by a disappearance of the pulse.

Option B: Halsted Test (Costoclavicular Manoeuvre):

The examiner locates the radial pulse and draws the patient's shoulder down and back as the patient lifts their chest in an exaggerated "attention' posture.

Inference: A positive test is indicated by an absence of a pulse.

Option C: Wright Test (Hyperabduction Manoeuvre)

Patients arm is hyper abducted to 180 and externally rotated

Inference: loss of radial pulse suggests compression

Option D: Roos test or EAST Test (Elevated Arm Stress Test):

Method: The patient has both arms in the 90" abduction-external rotation position, The patient is to open and close the hands slowly over a 3-minute period.

Inference: Reproduction of symptoms suggests compression.
